qas.question: Who called for Korean elections in 1950?
What did Kim Il-Sung do after the peace overture was rejected?
Why did Kim's war plan need revising?

answers.text: South Korean agents had learned about the plans

qas.question: When did Kim Il-Sung call for the Haeju conference?

context: On 7 June 1950, <a0_0>Kim Il-sung<a0_0/> called for a Korea-wide election on 5–8 August 1950 and a consultative conference in Haeju on 15–17 June <a4_0>1950<a4_0/>. On 11 June, the North sent three diplomats to the South, as a peace overture that <a1_0>Rhee<a1_0/> rejected. On 21 June, Kim Il-Sung <a2_0>revised his war plan<a2_0/> to involve general attack across the 38th parallel, rather than a limited operation in the Ongjin peninsula. Kim was concerned that <a3_0>South Korean agents had learned about the plans<a3_0/> and South Korean forces were strengthening their defenses. Stalin agreed to this change of plan.
